BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 29, 1923

UNITED STATES CIVIL SERVICE EXAMINATIONS BEING HELD
Open Competitive Examinations
as "Reconstruction Aides"
and "Reconstruction Pupil
Aides"
The United States Civil Service Commission announces the
following open competitive examination:
Application will be rated as received until further notice. The
examination are to fill vacancies
in the Public Health Service and
Veterans' Bureau throughout the
United States and vacancies in
positions requiring similar qualifications.
The entrance salaries for reconstruction aids in the Public
Health Service range from $720
to $960 a year, plus the increase
of $20 a month, and in addition
appointees will be allowed quarters, subsistence and laundry.
Reconstruction pupil aides are
not required in this service.
The entrance salaries for reconstruction aides in the Veterans' Bureau range from $1,680
to $2,500 a year, and the entrance
salaries for reconstruction pupil
aides range from $1,000 to $1,400
a year. Where quarters, subsistence, and laundry are available

THESE EXAMS
The examination system now in force in American colleges posesses many obvious disadvantages. Foremost among these is the
!s ulting strain upon the nervous system of the student, which strain
as, in severe and extreme cases, been. known to produce temporary
1Ea ad mild forms of insanity.
In the great majority of colleges this disadvantage and danger
is been minimized by allowing'the student ample time for preparaon and by spreading the examinations over a sufficient period. At
rinceton, for instance, the students are allowed ten days'in which
I prepare and then the examinations are only held on later days.
At Johns Hopkins the tendency has been to crowd them into as
7ief a period as possible. Formerly, one day was allowed before
lals and the examinations were evenly distributed throughout one
eek. This year, not only was the one day's interim eliminated, but
.e finals were crowded, for the most part, into the first few days.
Jristances have arisen where men have been forced to take five examiLtions in the first two days and four three-hour exams on Monday
a td Tuesday are the rule rather than the exception.
- We are not asking for an introduction of the Princeton system
al Ld we realize the difficulties which accompany the fixing of 'a. satisfa ctory examination schedule. It does seem essential, however, that
the period allotted to mid-years and finals be lengthened and that the
ex aminations be more evenly distributed. If one week proves insufient we see no obstacle in the way of allowing ten days or a fortflI: ht.
Twelve hours of examinations in two days is not only unsatisfa:tory ; it is dangerous..
VISITORS
When a man is in the privacy of his own home, unobserved by
th e outside world, he is not always so careful of his apirearance or of
hi ; actions. When confronted by strange eyes, however, when every
NV )rd and every'deed may be used "against him, he becomes more cauti us and acquires a certain polish and finesse.
Beginning the latter part of next week, Johns Hopkins will play
host to several hundred strangers, many of whom are paying their
fir 3t visit to the University and receiving their first impresson.
Ahers, fathers and sweethearts of the undergraduates together
with returning alumni and their families, will be daily witnesses of
th: life and the activities of the student body.
During June Week Johnny Hopkins should be on his best beha vior. Actions which may go unobserved
...
.._
. in our own family circle
Hi .y create a bad impression in the mind of an outsider. We are
co mizant of each other's little idiosyncrasies and petty shortcomin s and can easily forgive them. To a stranger, however, a man is
no: an individual, but is a student of Johns Hopkins. His actions
re Feet credit or discredit, as the case may be, upon the University.
The good name of Hopkins, therefore, is dependent upon the Conduct
c each man. We feel that we need say no more.

James II is DeadNEWTON Lives
T has always been known
that free bodies fall. The
earth has a strange attraction. How far does it
extend? No one knew before
Newton,sitting in his garden,one
day in 1665, began to speculate.
"Why should not the attraction
of gravitation reach as far as the
moon?" he asked himself. "And
ifso, perhaps she is retained in her
ofbit thereby." He began the calculation, but overwhelmed by the
stupendous result that he foresaw,
he had to beg a friend to complete it.
In Newton's Principia were laid
down his famous laws of motion
-the basis of all modern engineering. The universe was proved to
be a huge mechanism, the parts
of which are held together in accordance with the great law of
gravitation.
James H was reigning when

b;

the Principia appeared in 1687.
He is remembered for the Bloody
Assizes ofJeffreys,for his complete
disregard of constitutional liberties, for his secret compacts with
Louis XIV and the huge bribes
that he took from that monarch,
and for the revolution that cost
him his crown; Newton is remembered because he created a new
world of thought, because he enabled scientists and engineers who
came after him to grapple more
effectively with the forces of
nature.
When,far instance,the Research
Laboratories of the General Electric Company determine the
stresses set up in a steam turbine
by the enormous centrifugal forces
generated as the rotor spins, they
practically apply Newton's laws in
reaching conclusions that are of
the utmost value to the designing
engineer.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MAY 29, 1923
TENNIS TEAM CONCLUDES
SEASON BY MATCH
WITH "MEDS"
With a match between the
"Homewoodians" and the Medical
School, the Black and Blue tennis
team will conclude a successful season this Saturday.
In this "civil war" the odds favor the Homewood players, although Wilson and Burlinghof, as
the nucleus of the Medical team,
are expected to offer stiff opposition. Just what the other students
of medicine will be able to do is
unknown as the burden of studies
falls heavily upon each student, preventing much outside work. However, two natives of the Philippine
Islands, who played in some of the
earlier matches," are expected to
keep their opponents busy.
After a rather dubious start, the
Hopkins net team, aided by the two
candidates from the Medical School
and stiff practice with various tennis stars of the city, found itself
and finished the seasOn with a string
.of victories. Included in these victo-ir es are wins over-Delaware arid
Loyola and a tie with the University of Maryland. Unfortunately,
this tie match will not be played
off, because of the lateness of the
season.
The individual stars of the year
have been Captain Hofmeister,
Wasserman and Wilson. The work
of these three men figured in every
victory. Hofmeister is well-known
in local sport circles and, although
only a sophomore, played such a
good brand of tennis in his Freshman year that he was elected captain for the past season. Before
coming to Hopkins, Hofmeister
played for City College and one of
the local park teams. Wasserman,
also a former City College racquetter, is playing his first season for
Hopkins. His steadiness and forehand driving combined, make him
one of the most feared players -on
the team. Wilson plays the hardest game of the trig and, as shown
in his match with Weber, of Maryland, is at his best against a player
who continually lobs.
Prospects for next year are particularly bright, as most of the reserve men are freshmen. The formation of a freshman team early
this spring with Fonda, captain, and
Stulman, manager, also will give
next year's team an experienced
group to draw from.

CROUT CHOSEN PRESIDENT
OF CIVIL ENGINEERING
SOCIETY
Last Monday, at a meeting of
the Hopkins student chapter of
the American Society of Civil Engineers, officers for the next scholastic year were elected. These
are as -follows:
President — William North
Crout.
Vice-President
Clayton C.
Singleton.
• Secretary—J. Wysong.
Treasurer—Robert B. Burgess.
James H. Wills, the retiring
president,. made a brief address
thanking the members for their
continued Support during the last
year.,. He_spoke._of _ this _. year . as
(ine of the most successful in the
history .of the. student chapter.
Wills called upon the newly
chosen officers to - carry • on the
work started this season.
President Crout then took the
chair and publicly expressed his
appreciation of the work of the
retiring officers: 11"e, with the
other new .officers, formed plans
for holding an organization meeting next fall, immediately following the beginning of the scholastic year. The purpose of this
meeting will be to tell the incoming sophomores the aims and
laws of the society.

UNITED STATES CIVIL SERVICE EXAMINATIONS BEING HELD
Open Competitive Examinations
as "Reconstruction Aides"
and "Reconstruction Pupil
Aides"
The United States Civil Service Commission announces the
following open competitive examination:
Application will be rated as received until further notice. The
examination are to fill vacancies
in the Public Health Service and
Veterans' Bureau throughout the
United States and vacancies in
positions requiring similar qualifications.
The entrance salaries for reconstruction aids in the Public
Health Service range from $720
to $960 a year, plus the increase
of $20 a month, and in addition
appointees will be allowed quarters, subsistence and laundry.
Reconstruction pupil aides are
not required in this service.
The entrance salaries for reconstruction aides in the Veterans' Bureau range from $1,680
to $2,500 a year, and the entrance
salaries for reconstruction pupil
aides range from $1,000 to $1,400
a year. Where quarters, subsistence, and laundry are available

THESE EXAMS
The examination system now in force in American colleges posesses many obvious disadvantages. Foremost among these is the
!s ulting strain upon the nervous system of the student, which strain
as, in severe and extreme cases, been. known to produce temporary
1Ea ad mild forms of insanity.
In the great majority of colleges this disadvantage and danger
is been minimized by allowing'the student ample time for preparaon and by spreading the examinations over a sufficient period. At
rinceton, for instance, the students are allowed ten days'in which
I prepare and then the examinations are only held on later days.
At Johns Hopkins the tendency has been to crowd them into as
7ief a period as possible. Formerly, one day was allowed before
lals and the examinations were evenly distributed throughout one
eek. This year, not only was the one day's interim eliminated, but
.e finals were crowded, for the most part, into the first few days.
Jristances have arisen where men have been forced to take five examiLtions in the first two days and four three-hour exams on Monday
a td Tuesday are the rule rather than the exception.
- We are not asking for an introduction of the Princeton system
al Ld we realize the difficulties which accompany the fixing of 'a. satisfa ctory examination schedule. It does seem essential, however, that
the period allotted to mid-years and finals be lengthened and that the
ex aminations be more evenly distributed. If one week proves insufient we see no obstacle in the way of allowing ten days or a fortflI: ht.
Twelve hours of examinations in two days is not only unsatisfa:tory ; it is dangerous..
VISITORS
When a man is in the privacy of his own home, unobserved by
th e outside world, he is not always so careful of his apirearance or of
hi ; actions. When confronted by strange eyes, however, when every
NV )rd and every'deed may be used "against him, he becomes more cauti us and acquires a certain polish and finesse.
Beginning the latter part of next week, Johns Hopkins will play
host to several hundred strangers, many of whom are paying their
fir 3t visit to the University and receiving their first impresson.
Ahers, fathers and sweethearts of the undergraduates together
with returning alumni and their families, will be daily witnesses of
th: life and the activities of the student body.
During June Week Johnny Hopkins should be on his best beha vior. Actions which may go unobserved
...
.._
. in our own family circle
Hi .y create a bad impression in the mind of an outsider. We are
co mizant of each other's little idiosyncrasies and petty shortcomin s and can easily forgive them. To a stranger, however, a man is
no: an individual, but is a student of Johns Hopkins. His actions
re Feet credit or discredit, as the case may be, upon the University.
The good name of Hopkins, therefore, is dependent upon the Conduct
c each man. We feel that we need say no more.

James II is DeadNEWTON Lives
T has always been known
that free bodies fall. The
earth has a strange attraction. How far does it
extend? No one knew before
Newton,sitting in his garden,one
day in 1665, began to speculate.
"Why should not the attraction
of gravitation reach as far as the
moon?" he asked himself. "And
ifso, perhaps she is retained in her
ofbit thereby." He began the calculation, but overwhelmed by the
stupendous result that he foresaw,
he had to beg a friend to complete it.
In Newton's Principia were laid
down his famous laws of motion
-the basis of all modern engineering. The universe was proved to
be a huge mechanism, the parts
of which are held together in accordance with the great law of
gravitation.
James H was reigning when

b;

the Principia appeared in 1687.
He is remembered for the Bloody
Assizes ofJeffreys,for his complete
disregard of constitutional liberties, for his secret compacts with
Louis XIV and the huge bribes
that he took from that monarch,
and for the revolution that cost
him his crown; Newton is remembered because he created a new
world of thought, because he enabled scientists and engineers who
came after him to grapple more
effectively with the forces of
nature.
When,far instance,the Research
Laboratories of the General Electric Company determine the
stresses set up in a steam turbine
by the enormous centrifugal forces
generated as the rotor spins, they
practically apply Newton's laws in
reaching conclusions that are of
the utmost value to the designing
engineer.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MAY 29, 1923
TENNIS TEAM CONCLUDES
SEASON BY MATCH
WITH "MEDS"
With a match between the
"Homewoodians" and the Medical
School, the Black and Blue tennis
team will conclude a successful season this Saturday.
In this "civil war" the odds favor the Homewood players, although Wilson and Burlinghof, as
the nucleus of the Medical team,
are expected to offer stiff opposition. Just what the other students
of medicine will be able to do is
unknown as the burden of studies
falls heavily upon each student, preventing much outside work. However, two natives of the Philippine
Islands, who played in some of the
earlier matches," are expected to
keep their opponents busy.
After a rather dubious start, the
Hopkins net team, aided by the two
candidates from the Medical School
and stiff practice with various tennis stars of the city, found itself
and finished the seasOn with a string
.of victories. Included in these victo-ir es are wins over-Delaware arid
Loyola and a tie with the University of Maryland. Unfortunately,
this tie match will not be played
off, because of the lateness of the
season.
The individual stars of the year
have been Captain Hofmeister,
Wasserman and Wilson. The work
of these three men figured in every
victory. Hofmeister is well-known
in local sport circles and, although
only a sophomore, played such a
good brand of tennis in his Freshman year that he was elected captain for the past season. Before
coming to Hopkins, Hofmeister
played for City College and one of
the local park teams. Wasserman,
also a former City College racquetter, is playing his first season for
Hopkins. His steadiness and forehand driving combined, make him
one of the most feared players -on
the team. Wilson plays the hardest game of the trig and, as shown
in his match with Weber, of Maryland, is at his best against a player
who continually lobs.
Prospects for next year are particularly bright, as most of the reserve men are freshmen. The formation of a freshman team early
this spring with Fonda, captain, and
Stulman, manager, also will give
next year's team an experienced
group to draw from.

Last Monday, at a meeting of
the Hopkins student chapter of
the American Society of Civil Engineers, officers for the next scholastic year were elected. These
are as -follows:
President — William North
Crout.
Vice-President
Clayton C.
Singleton.

James H. Wills, the retiring
president,. made a brief address
thanking the members for their
continued Support during the last
year.,. He_spoke._of _ this _. year . as
(ine of the most successful in the
history .of the. student chapter.
Wills called upon the newly
chosen officers to - carry • on the
work started this season.
President Crout then took the
chair and publicly expressed his
appreciation of the work of the
retiring officers: 11"e, with the
other new .officers, formed plans
for holding an organization meeting next fall, immediately following the beginning of the scholastic year. The purpose of this

laws of the society.
